headline.main: Searching for a New Way to Treat Bulimia

docs.abstract: Article on medical study being undertaken in Greenwich, Conn, funded by National Institute of Health grant, to find alternative ways to treat bulimia; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHETHER it was prompted by the pressures of growing up in an upper middle-class suburb, or whether it was genetic or just bad luck, somewhere along the line a 41-year old Greenwich woman lost the ability to deal with stress, feelings and problems. Instead, she found comfort in food, using binge eating and purging by vomiting to relieve stress. Like an estimated 1 to 2 percent of women between the ages of 16 and 35 in the United States, she became bulimic. ''I've struggled with it off and on since college,'' said the woman, who requested anonymity. ''I don't think I've ever been free of the desire for more than a few months at a time in all my adult life.''
docs.snippet: WHETHER it was prompted by the pressures of growing up in an upper middle-class suburb, or whether it was genetic or just bad luck, somewhere along the line a 41-year old Greenwich woman lost the ability to deal with stress, feelings and problems.   ...

headline.main: For Teen-Age Girls, It's Cool to Be a Scout

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column: changes in Girls Scouts that are helping to attract increasing number of members discussed; psychologist Virginia Porcello, director of Solutions Program for Eating Disorders in Roslyn Heights, comments on what it means to be fat (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: LEANING her long, thin frame against the flip chart, Theresa Mantello, 16, of Hicksville looked every bit the modern teen-ager. Her blond hair was haphazardly clipped back in a ponytail. She was sporting a tight white shirt with just a hint of bellybutton exposed above low-slung bell-bottom jeans. But when she started writing topic headings on the chart with a Kelly green marker for a women's issues forum, it became clear that Theresa was a Girl Scout. Just a few years ago, Theresa would have been ashamed to admit she belonged to a troop. But there she was the other evening, chatting with other high-school-age scouts at a Senior Program Advisory Team meeting at the Girl Scouts of Nassau County headquarters in Garden City. Although she hardly ever wears the uniform and wished the postcard announcing the annual Girl Scout-Boy Scout social looked a bit funkier, Theresa has come out as a scout.

headline.main: New Diet Drug Sells Well, But It Didn't Set a Record

docs.abstract: Hoffmann-LaRoche's diet drug Xenical will not go down as most successful new pharmaceutical in history, but analysts remain confident that it will become best seller; Xenical accounted for 96,485 prescriptions during its first four week on the market; graph (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: After one month on the market, the diet drug Xenical, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, will not go down as the most successful new pharmaceutical in history, but analysts remain confident that it will become a best seller. Xenical, which the Food and Drug Administration approved in late April, accounted for 96,485 prescriptions during its first four weeks on the market. By contrast, Viagra, Pfizer's impotency pill, and Celebrex, Monsanto's arthritis drug, had prescriptions in their first months of 367,857 and 150,113, respectively, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant. The introductions of Viagra and Celebrex were two of the most successful in pharmaceutical history.

docs.abstract: Dr Robert C Atkins letter replies to Jane E Brody's May 25 Personal Health column raising some questions about Atkins low-carbohydrate diet
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jane Brody in her Personal Health column continues to attack the Atkins diet (''Doubts Fail to Deter the Diet Revolution'') despite 40 years of positive clinical experience and hundreds of publications supporting the diet's safety and efficacy.

headline.main: For Good Health, It Helps To Be Rich and Important

docs.abstract: Research demonstrates that social class--as measured not just by income but also by education and other markers of relative status--is one of most powerful predictors of health, more powerful than genetics, exposure to carcinogens, even smoking; shows that with wide variety of illnesses, the higher the rung on the socioeconomic ladder, the lower the risk; relationship holds even at upper reaches of society, where it might seem that abundance of resources would even things out; gap in life expectancy between blacks and white decreases substantially once socioeconomic status is taken into account; graph (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors usually evaluate patients' vulnerability to serious disease by inquiring about risk factors like cigarette smoking, obesity, hypertension and high cholesterol. But they might be better off asking how much money those patients make, how many years they spent in school and where they stand relative to others in their offices and communities.
